title: Environment Modules
text: Currently EnvironmentModules CRAN, install follows:

title: Environment Modules
text: can list available modules: can filter modules starting prefix:

title: Environment Modules
text: Load modules using module_load()! ’ve already loaded module, notified: can unload module using corresponding module_unload():

title: Environment Modules
text: can list modules already loaded module_list():

title: Environment Modules
text: Although module_load() add module’s libraries LD_LIBRARY_PATH, allow compile packages , R necessarily able actually run packages use libraries. example, let’s say want use hdf5r package, depends hdf5 library package. don’t hdf5 loaded, fail: Let’s see happens load appropriate module. Firstly, need find module called: can now load module: Now let’s try : Finally, can load package … can ? alluded , R doesn’t actually load every new library becomes available environment. Rather uses “load-time linking”, libraries links fixed time start R. Now, can resolve error closing R, loading module, restarting R, can quite annoying. Fortunately package supports installing packages special way hints package find modules needs. means won’t restart R, even load modules next time want use package: worked! interested theory underlying happening , might find Linux’s ld.manual page interesting. Either run man ld.Linux, visit page: https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/ld..8.html. Specifically, package uses DT_RPATH approach dependency resolution.
code: install.packages("hdf5r", quiet=TRUE) module_avail("hdf5") module_load("hdf5/1.12.2") install.packages("hdf5r", quiet=TRUE) library(hdf5r) install.packages("hdf5r", quiet=TRUE) |> with_module_install() library(hdf5r)

title: Environment Modules
text: package also supports following. module_swap() unloads first module loads second: module_purge() unloads modules:

title: Environment Modules
text: want use feature Environment Modules (yet) dedicated function, can use advanced functions get_module_code get_module_output. want run command doesn’t edit modules, shows output, run get_module_output module edit modules, use get_module_code(), evaluate result:

title: Environment Modules
text: Environment Modules supports loading modules R since version 4.0.0! point package? true, actually package just wrapper around core functionality. need Modules version 4.0.0 run package. main advantages using wrapper nicer function interfaces, nice documentation, ability automatically “bake ” modules packages install. ’m getting error “detect Environment Modules installation”, know Environment Modules installed system. ? First, bash terminal module command works correctly, run modulecmd. R, run Sys.setenv(MODULES_CMD="</path//modulecmd>"), putting output previous step argument value. everything work!

title: Authors and Citation
text: Michael Milton. Maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Milton M (2023). EnvironmentModules: user friendly R front-end Environment Modules system. https://wehi-researchcomputing.github.io/EnvironmentModules/, https://github.com/WEHI-ResearchComputing/EnvironmentModules.
code: @Manual{,   title = {EnvironmentModules: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system},   author = {Michael Milton},   year = {2023},   note = {https://wehi-researchcomputing.github.io/EnvironmentModules/, https://github.com/WEHI-ResearchComputing/EnvironmentModules}, }

what: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: EnvironmentModules package R front-end Environment Modules project, offers way load unload packages, commonly used shared HPC (High Performance Computing) environments.

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: Currently EnvironmentModules CRAN, install follows:

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: can list available modules: can filter modules starting prefix:
code: module_avail() ------------------- /stornext/System/data/modulefiles/tools -------------------- apptainer/1.0.0              mpich-slurm/3.3.2                   wine/6.9       apptainer/1.1.0              mpich-slurm/3.4.1                   wine/7.17      aspera/3.5.4                 mpich-slurm/3.4.2                   zeromq/4.3.4   aspera/3.9.1                 mpich/3.3                           zstd/1.5.0     aspera/3.9.6                 mpich/3.3.2                          awscli/1.16py2.7             ncftp/3.2.6                          awscli/1.16py3.7             nextflow/22.04.5                     awscli/1.22.89               nextflow/22.10.4                     awscli/2.1.25                ninja/1.10.0                         awscli/2.5.2                 nmap-ncat/7.91                       axel/2.17.10                 nodejs/10.24.1                       bazel/0.26.1                 nodejs/16.19.0                       bazel/1.2.1                  nodejs/17.9.1                        binutils/2.35.2-gcc-4.8.5    ocl-icd/2.3.1                        binutils/2.35.2-gcc-9.1.0    octave/6.4.0-gcc11.1.0               cluster-utils/18.08.1        oneMKL/2022.1.0.223                  cmake/3.25.1                 openBLAS/0.3.6-gcc-9.1.0             CUnit/2.1-3                  openBLAS/0.3.21-gcc-11.1.0           curl/7.65.0                  openBLAS/0.3.21-gcc-11.1.0-skylake   .... module_avail("python") ----------------- /stornext/System/data/modulefiles/bioinf/its ----------------- python/2.7.18  python/3.5.3        python/3.7.0   python/3.8.3  python/3.9.5    python/3.5.1   python/3.6.5-intel  python/3.7.13  python/3.8.8  python/3.10.4    Key: modulepath  default-version

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: Load modules using module_load()! ’ve already loaded module, notified: can unload module using corresponding module_unload():
code: module_load("python/3") #> ✔ Successfully loaded python/3 module_load("python/3") #> ℹ Nothing to do. This module was probably already loaded. Use module_list() to verify. module_unload("python/3") #> ✔ Successfully unloaded python/3

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: can list modules already loaded module_list():
code: module_load("python/3") #> ✔ Successfully loaded python/3 module_list() Currently Loaded Modulefiles:  1) python/3.8.8    Key: default-version

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: Although module_load() add module’s libraries LD_LIBRARY_PATH, allow compile packages , R necessarily able actually run packages use libraries. example, let’s say want use hdf5r package, depends hdf5 library package. don’t hdf5 loaded, fail: Let’s see happens load appropriate module. Firstly, need find module called: can now load module: Now let’s try : Finally, can load package … can ? alluded , R doesn’t actually load every new library becomes available environment. Rather uses “load-time linking”, libraries links fixed time start R. Now, can resolve error closing R, loading module, restarting R, can quite annoying. Fortunately package supports installing packages special way hints package find modules needs. means won’t restart R, even load modules next time want use package: worked! interested theory underlying happening , might find Linux’s ld.manual page interesting. Either run man ld.Linux, visit page: https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/ld..8.html. Specifically, package uses DT_RPATH approach dependency resolution.
code: install.packages("hdf5r", quiet=TRUE) #> Warning in install.packages : #>   installation of package 'hdf5r' had non-zero exit status module_avail("hdf5") ------------------- /stornext/System/data/modulefiles/tools -------------------- hdf5-mpich/1.10.5_3.3    ----------------- /stornext/System/data/modulefiles/bioinf/its ----------------- hdf5/1.8.16  hdf5/1.8.20  hdf5/1.8.21  hdf5/1.10.5  hdf5/1.12.1  hdf5/1.12.2    Key: modulepath  default-version module_load("hdf5/1.12.2") #> ✔ Successfully loaded hdf5/1.12.2 install.packages("hdf5r", quiet=TRUE) library(hdf5r) #> Error: package or namespace load failed for 'hdf5r' in dyn.load(file, DLLpath = DLLpath, ...): #>  unable to load shared object '/stornext/Home/data/allstaff/m/milton.m/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.2/hdf5r/libs/hdf5r.so': #>   libhdf5_hl.so.200: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory install.packages("hdf5r", quiet=TRUE) |> with_module_install() library(hdf5r)

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: package also supports following. module_swap() unloads first module loads second: module_purge() unloads modules:

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: want use feature Environment Modules (yet) dedicated function, can use advanced functions get_module_code get_module_output. want run command doesn’t edit modules, shows output, run get_module_output module edit modules, use get_module_code(), evaluate result:
code: get_module_output(c("show", "hdf5")) ------------------------------------------------------------------- /stornext/System/data/modulefiles/bioinf/its/hdf5/1.12.1:  module-whatis    {HDF5 is a unique technology suite that makes possible the management of extremely large and complex data collections. (v1.12.1)} conflict hdf5 prepend-path PATH /stornext/System/data/apps/hdf5/hdf5-1.12.1/bin prepend-path CPATH /stornext/System/data/apps/hdf5/hdf5-1.12.1/include prepend-path LD_LIBRARY_PATH /stornext/System/data/apps/hdf5/hdf5-1.12.1/lib prepend-path LIBRARY_PATH /stornext/System/data/apps/hdf5/hdf5-1.12.1/lib prepend-path MANPATH :/stornext/System/data/apps/hdf5/hdf5-1.12.1/share/man ------------------------------------------------------------------- get_module_code("reload") |> eval() #> NULL

title: A user friendly R front-end for the Environment Modules system
text: Environment Modules supports loading modules R since version 4.0.0! point package? true, actually package just wrapper around core functionality. need Modules version 4.0.0 run package. main advantages using wrapper nicer function interfaces, nice documentation, ability automatically “bake ” modules packages install. ’m getting error “detect Environment Modules installation”, know Environment Modules installed system. ? First, bash terminal module command works correctly, run modulecmd. R, run Sys.setenv(MODULES_CMD="</path//modulecmd>"), putting output previous step argument value. everything work!

what: Ensures Environment Modules is above a certain version — check_version
title: Ensures Environment Modules is above a certain version — check_version
text: Asserts current Environment Modules version specified version. Raises error .

title: Ensures Environment Modules is above a certain version — check_version
code: check_version(   against = MIN_SUPPORTED_VERSION,   action = "for the function you just ran" )

title: Ensures Environment Modules is above a certain version — check_version
text: version check . default minimum version supported package. action character scalar describing action attempted, infinitive conjugation (e.g. "run X" "running Y")

title: Ensures Environment Modules is above a certain version — check_version
text: invisible value whose value may changed future.

title: Ensures Environment Modules is above a certain version — check_version

what: Returns a vector of currently loaded environment modules — get_loaded_modules
title: Returns a vector of currently loaded environment modules — get_loaded_modules
text: Returns vector currently loaded environment modules

title: Returns a vector of currently loaded environment modules — get_loaded_modules
Returns a vector of currently loaded environment modules — get_loaded_modules
text: character vector, one entry per module

title: Returns a vector of currently loaded environment modules — get_loaded_modules

what: Returns the R code that would execute a given module command — get_module_code
title: Returns the R code that would execute a given module command — get_module_code
text: Returns R code execute given module command

title: Returns the R code that would execute a given module command — get_module_code
Returns the R code that would execute a given module command — get_module_code
text: args character vector defining module command. need include word "module". example module load zeromq bash converted run_modulecmd(c("load", "zeromq")) env character vector containing KEY=VALUE entries named vector defining additional environment variables set

title: Returns the R code that would execute a given module command — get_module_code
text: expression object containing R code produced command

title: Returns the R code that would execute a given module command — get_module_code

what: Evaluates a module command, and returns the text output. — get_module_output
title: Evaluates a module command, and returns the text output. — get_module_output
text: Evaluates module command, returns text output.

title: Evaluates a module command, and returns the text output. — get_module_output
Evaluates a module command, and returns the text output. — get_module_output
text: args character vector defining module command. need include word "module". example module load zeromq bash converted run_modulecmd(c("load", "zeromq")) env character vector containing KEY=VALUE entries named vector defining additional environment variables set

title: Evaluates a module command, and returns the text output. — get_module_output
text: character vector class "cli_ansi_string".

title: Evaluates a module command, and returns the text output. — get_module_output

what: Gets the file path to the modulescmd executable — get_modulescmd_binary
title: Gets the file path to the modulescmd executable — get_modulescmd_binary
text: Gets file path modulescmd executable

title: Gets the file path to the modulescmd executable — get_modulescmd_binary
Gets the file path to the modulescmd executable — get_modulescmd_binary
text: character scalar containing full file path modulescmd executable

what: Get the current Environment Modules version — get_version
title: Get the current Environment Modules version — get_version
text: can e.g. used enable/disable functionality based whether current version supports .

what: Lists all modules available to be loaded — module_avail
title: Lists all modules available to be loaded — module_avail
text: Lists modules available loaded

title: Lists all modules available to be loaded — module_avail
Lists all modules available to be loaded — module_avail
text: starts_with optional character scalar. provided, modules whose name starts character string returned. contains optional character scalar. parameter supported Environment Modules 4.3+. provided, filter modules containing substring.

what: Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
title: Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
text: Executes package installation command installed package aware modules currently loaded. means can load package without needing load module later, also can load package now, without restarting R session.

title: Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
text: expr R code want run installs packages. time just call install.packages

title: Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
text: result evaluating expr

title: Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
text: functionality performed setting temporary value LDFLAGS environment variable Makevars file. work R package set correctly use LDFLAGS, correctly configured R packages automatically . Also, recommended minimal number modules needed install package loaded run .

title: Bake environment modules into an R package — with_module_install
code: options(repos=c(CRAN="https://cloud.r-project.org/")) module_load("hdf5") #> ✔ Successfully loaded hdf5 install.packages("hdf5r") |> with_module_install() #> Error in install.packages : Updating loaded packages
